title: Car Salesman Illaoi
body: Her tentacles are the inflatable tube guys.

replies.body: Saleswoman...

Actually a new wave of politically correctness is sweeping where you aren't supposed to distinguish between man and woman in job titles (everyone is a waiter not a waitress, actors not actresses, etc.), so you can disagree with doing that, but your correction here is technically wrong in the current meta of formally correct English language.

http://www.lapollonio.com/images/rap_battle.gif

You JUST REKT HIM GG
Lol wasn't trying to rek, just inform. I just like to point out when people correct others' grammar or word choice when the corrector is  actually wrong or both options would be correct.
I know just wanted to use that gif.{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

> [{quoted}](name=drbob2012,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=4m9Ac34i,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2015-11-28T17:08:22.984+0000)
>
> Actually a new wave of politically correctness is sweeping where you aren't supposed to distinguish between man and woman in job titles (everyone is a waiter not a waitress, actors not actresses, etc.), so you can disagree with doing that, but your correction here is technically wrong in the current meta of formally correct English language.

*Salesperson :P
That is actually inaccurate. You do that when you don't know or don't want to assume someone's gender. If you know it you must use the correct gender and proper words and terms that go with it.

Most English nouns are not actually marked for gender, so they are neutral unless you specifically add something feminine like ess, ette, woman, etc. For words that actually do end in man like salesman, fireman, chairman, it is considered most of the time to still be neutral (despite the fact that in common speech man usually does specifically mean a male, man can mean a member of the human species of either gender); however, if you really want to be absolutely "politically correct," which is what I was talking about btw, your best bet is to just say sales person/associate, fire fighter, or chair person.
Illaoi is a woman. You know she is a woman. She doesn't identify as anything but a woman. So the correct way is "saleswoman."

> For words that actually do end in man like salesman, fireman, chairman, it is considered most of the time to still be neutral (despite the fact that in common speech man usually does specifically mean a male, man can mean a member of the human species of either gender)

         Did you miss this the first time around, friend? Oh, and her self-identification has nothing to do with it. Salesmen is gender neutral. Just like when someone says "The dawn of man," well, they don't ever mean just those things with the dangly bits between their legs, they mean all of mankind...all of humanity. 
         On a similar note, the Star Trek Captain's Oath change from "To go where no MAN has gone before" to "To go where no ONE has gone before." Good job, you "avoided sexism" or whatever....only problem being that man, here, referred to humanity as a species. If you are out exploring and you find other species, clearly some ONE HAS been there before. But if this is the outmost limit to where humanity has explored, then you are truly going where no MAN has gone before.

You are the one missing the whole point.

1st- This discussion ends when you know a person/character identifies as a gender. So there is no need to discuss about gender neutral pronouns/words. Illaoi is a woman. So the correct title should be "saleswoman." No need to use a gender neutral form for a person/character that identifies as a certain gender. So your whole comment is unnecessary. 

2nd- We could talk about gender neutral language, but it is absolutely offtopic. And we would go on and on about how sexism and centuries of patriarchy shaped many languages so the male form is always the default form and how new ways of thought consider the introduction of actual neutral forms like certain languages already have. 
But as said this is offtopic and has no place in this thread.
I really want to use that gif again now.

> [{quoted}](name=drbob2012,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=4m9Ac34i,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2015-11-28T17:08:22.984+0000)

> Actually a new wave of politically correctness is sweeping where you aren't supposed to distinguish between man and woman in job titles (everyone is a waiter not a waitress, actors not actresses, etc.), so you can disagree with doing that, but your correction here is technically wrong in the current meta of formally correct English language.


Just because America has bs political correctness doesn't mean the UK or Ireland has it. Not everything is centered around US you know?

OP is American, so my comment still stands, and my whole point isn't "Duke Anax y u so dumb?" My point is that if he was saying that as a serious correction he's a bit of a douche for being a grammar nazi that's not even correct. The same applies to that Fenrir Epsylon guy.

We never stop... with these amazing deals!

Chase is what is desired... so buy this new model now!
Life is too short for fear... so get this top of the line safety-rating car!

Should never enforce political correctness though.  That just another form of censorship in my opinion one that is being used inappropriately.  Telling other people that they offend others from misrepresentation is wrong.  Then again,  considering when people try to use this detached way of thinking whats the point in trying to correct others?  Look at Walmart as an example.  They went from "Happy Holidays" this year to "Merry Christmas."  Political sensibilities and offending people should not be confused.  Saleswoman is just find.  I hate when people try to force their way of thinking onto others even though it's not necessarily correct ether.
Wrong thread ?
